User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1
Build ID: 20110928134238

Steps to reproduce:

Open this page, (which contains an OpenSocial 1.0 specification):

https://opensocial-resources.googlecode.com/svn/spec/1.0/Core-Gadget.xml

This problem existed in FF 3.6 as well.


Actual results:

A long document appears, but it is layed-out wider than the width of the browser, and there are no scrollbars shown.

The workaround is to simply resize the browser to cause another reflow of the content.  Another thing that works is to invoke the "Find" action and then press ESC, as for some reason the find bar appearing at the bottom will cause a layout as well.


Expected results:

The page should be formatted to the width of the window, and the vertical scrollbar should be shown.
comments.author: randy.hudson@gmail.com
comments.creator: randy.hudson@gmail.com

comments.text:
This bug is definitely related to zoom, in fact it has two manifestations:

1. If zoom is positive, the page spills outside the page boundaries with no right-left scroll bar.

2. If zoom is negative, the page is weirdly truncated at the bottom and uses a narrower window than it should.

It does seem to be xslt related and I thought that it might also be https related but, no, I can reproduce under http. As other people have noted, jiggling the window size fixes the problem for the current view. FWIW, here's another page which reproduces the problem: http://sirius-software.com/alex/main.xml

It would seem that the rendering engine is not getting the correct window size when called for HTML generated by XSLT, at least immeiately after the XSLT has done its stuff.

*Please* could someone fix this? I basically have to tell our customers that Firefox just doesn't work right with our app and there's nothing I can do about it because the bug is in Firefox. FWIW, the bug occurs in both Firefox 15.0.1 under Windoze and 14.0.1 under linux (pretty much any version I've ever tried).
